newsitem.title: UK: AIC says Cargill slow with gas oil nominations.
newsitem.headline: AIC says Cargill slow with gas oil nominations.

text.p: Trading house AIC, the main short on the November IPE gas oil contract, said on Friday that Cargill, the main long, was behind on its nominations for the second five-day delivery window.
An AIC spokesperson said Cargill was 38 percent short on its nominations in the Amsterdam area and 60 percent short on its nominations in the Antwerp area.
"They are falling short on the amount they need to pick up ... If they are running short on nominations then how can we load their oil?" the spokesperson said.

He added that Cargill had indicated that it intended to lift 260,000 tonnes in the second 21-25 period that ends on Monday but it had a total of only five barges presented to its installations in Amsterdam and Antwerp for loading under the second window.
A spokesperson at Cargill's Minneapolis headquarters was not immediately available for comment. A Cargill trader in Geneva had no comment.
AIC earlier in the week said Cargill had failed to lift the required volume of gas oil in the first five-day period of the November 16-30 delivery window.

Cargill, in apparent reponse to that charge, said on Thursday there had been some problems in the first five-day delivery period but it hoped to resolve these through IPE channels. It added it was confident the IPE would resolve any dispute in a prompt and just manner.
Cargill is due to take delivery of at least 627,800 tonnes, of which a third each is due to be lifted in the three five-day periods, November 16-20, November 21-25 and November 26-30.
European gas oil traders have condemned the duel being fought between the two companies, saying it has sapped liquidity, disrupted supply patterns and damaged the IPE's price discovery function.
